items.name: Quema del Torito
items.description: This Guatemalan tradition, features a handmade, brightly decorated bull filled with fireworks that, when lit in front of churches, is carried by a person who dances and chases passersby.

items.name: El Carnaval
items.description: This festive celebration, held before Lent, features colorful parades, music, dancing, and costumes, with families and communities filling the streets to enjoy lively performances and playful traditions.

items.name: Danza de los Moros
items.description: A traditional theatrical dance that reenacts the battles between Moors and Christians, performed with elaborate costumes, masks, and choreography to preserve colonial-era cultural heritage.

items.name: Las Posadas
items.description: A nine-night Christmas tradition in which participants reenact Mary and Joseph’s search for lodging, moving in processions between homes and churches while singing carols and sharing food.

items.name: Paseo Cayalá
items.description: Paseo Cayalá is the commercial and cultural center of Ciudad Cayalá. Featuring Spanish-colonial–inspired architecture, public plazas, shops, restaurants, and quaint cultural spaces.

items.name: Torre del Reformador
items.description: The Torre del Reformador is a 75-meter tall iron tower inspired by the Eiffel Tower, built in 1935 as a monument to the liberal reformer Justo Rufino Barrios.

items.name: Zoológico La Aurora
items.description: Zoológico La Aurora houses a diverse collection of native and exotic animals within landscaped grounds and offers educational programs for visitors of all ages.

items.name: Catedral de Santiago
items.description: The Cathedral of Saint James is the main Catholic cathedral in Guatemala City, renowned for its baroque architecture, and both religious and historical importance.
